awd_titl_txt: Gravitational-Wave Inference from Binary Compact Objects
awd_abstract_narration:
In the coming years, beyond the first direct gravitational-wave detection that was announced in February 2016, LIGO observations will provide uniquely reliable answers to some of the most long-standing questions in astrophysics: e.g., What are the masses of black holes in binary systems formed in nature? What is the engine powering short-hard gamma-ray bursts? What is the maximum neutron star mass and what does it imply for matter at extreme densities? How fast do black holes spin? Can we distinguish between different astrophysical environments that form binary compact objects (black holes or neutron stars)? How do black-hole masses evolve with redshift and what can we learn about the delay times between their formation and their merger? The research supported by this grant couples gravitational-wave physics to applied mathematics and astrophysical modeling. The work focuses on developing a concrete framework for the processing of detections of binary compact object mergers by Advanced LIGO. The goals are to extract the maximal available astrophysical information for binaries with compact objects with any mass and spin configuration. 

Specifically the following two main research projects are targeted: (i) physical parameter estimation for compact-object coalescence events using advanced sampling methods, targeting the acceleration of parameter estimation simulations and results, using waveforms of maximal physical realism including numerical-relativity waveforms, accounting for non-Gaussian noise, and for improvements from electromagnetic counterpart detections; (ii) the calculation of astrophysical models of binary compact objects detected by Advanced LIGO and the use of LIGO observations to constrain such models. Furthermore, the involvement in public outreach activities is intended to strengthen the connection between astronomy and gravitational wave physics, by focusing on projects that explain the formation of the sources of these waves to the public.

por.por_cntn:
On 14 September 2015, the twin Advanced LIGO detectors made the first direct observation of gravitational waves. This marked the culmination of decades of experimental work — principally supported by the National Science Foundation — to construct instruments accurate enough to measure gravitational waves. From the observed gravitational-wave signal, we can infer the properties of the source system, enabling a revolutionary new form of astronomy.

This grant supported the development and implementation of techniques to analyze gravitational-wave signals, to uncover the properties of their sources. Analysis showed that the source of the first observed gravitational-wave signal was two black holes spiraling together and merging to form a bigger black hole. Each of the initial black holes was around 30 times the mass of our Sun. This was the first time black holes of this mass were observed, the first time a binary of two black holes were observed, and the first time a black hole was observed to be born from a merger. Combing our data analysis techniques with the new LIGO data has enabled the birth of the new field of gravitational-wave astronomy.

Since September 2015, there have been many more detections. The first two observing runs of Advanced LIGO, and its partner detector Advanced Virgo, included observations of 10 binary black hole mergers and one binary neutron star. As the gravitational-wave detectors improved, the rate of detections will increase, making it essential to have efficient analyzes. We have worked to improve our analysis techniques, apply them to real data, and characterize how we will perform in future observing runs.

The new catalog of gravitational-wave observations enables us to not only study the properties of individual sources, but to also consider the population. This enables us to discover how these binaries form, and determine the currently uncertain physics of how black holes and neutron stars form from stars. The grant has also support our work on how to interpret the growing population of gravitational-wave detections. With our existing small catalog, we can begin to constrain how many black holes there are of different masses — we currently infer that 99% of black holes in binaries are below 45 times the mass of our Sun. We have shown that with a few hundred events (as expected in the next few years) we will be able to use our gravitational-wave observations to measure the fraction of binaries formed in different ways, for example from isolated binaries of stars or dynamically in dense stellar environments like globular clusters.

Gravitational-wave astronomy is a new frontier of observational astronomy. Interpreting these observations and placing them in the context of existing astrophysics requires careful statistical analysis. We now have the foundations of these analyses in place. As the number of detections increases, we will soon be able to answer the key questions of how black holes and neutron stars are created.
